fields.help: Information about rights held in and over the resource. fields.label: rights

fields.help: A person or organization owning or managing rights over the resource. Example:  Copyright Regents of the University of California.
fields.mask: Default: Add names of the copyright holders of the corpus.
fields.value: Default: Add names of the copyright holders of the corpus.
fields.label: rightsHolder

fields.help: Entity/ies responsible for making contributions to the resource. A Contributor may be a person, an organization, or a service—any entity that has sufficient involvement in the creation or development of the resource to warrant explicit identification. A term from olac:role should be used to specify the role of the Contributor. Contributor is related to Creator since many of the terms in the role vocabulary (like author or photographer) name the role of the primary creator of a resource. The OLAC recommendation is that Contributor (with the appropriate role designation) be used in these cases, and that Creator be used only when there is not an appropriate term in the olac:role vocabulary for the role played by the entity that created the resource. A participating OLAC repository need not be concerned about the fact that other metadata services based on Dublin Core may prefer and even require the use of the Creator element. The OLAC-to-Simple-DC crosswalk built into the OLAC Aggregator automatically maps certain OLAC Contributor roles like author and photographer to the Creator element. See the discussion of Creator for more on its use. Follow the form in which the person's name would normally be listed in an alphabetical index in his or her own language or country of residence, e.g., “FamilyName, GivenName” for an English speaker. For examples see: http://www.language-archives.org/NOTE/usage.html
fields.label: contributor

fields.help: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource. It refers to an entity with a primary role in the creation of the intellectual or artistic content of the resource. For examples see: http://www.language-archives.org/NOTE/usage.html
fields.label: creator

fields.help: An entity responsible for making the resource available. The Publisher is generally the business, organization, or sometimes individual who takes responsibility (and provides financial and production resources) for putting the resource into a form suitable for making it publicly available, whether in multiple hard copies (printing, pressing of a disc, etc), by broadcasting (radio, television, webcast), or posting to a public website.
fields.label: publisher

fields.help: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.
fields.label: identifier

fields.help: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource.
fields.label: format

fields.help: The nature or genre of the resource (normally a dataset, but could also be a lexicon and/or a grammar).
fields.label: type

fields.help: The present resource may be derived from the Source resource in whole or in part.
fields.label: source

fields.help: A statement of any changes in ownership and custody of the resource since its creation that are significant for its authenticity, integrity and interpretation. Example: Collection of texts recorded by ____, transcribed with the assistance of a number of local residents. Body of materials were transferred to custody of SIL ____ Branch in 1980s, subsequently organized,  collated and annotated by J. L. ____, a researcher in a closely related _____ language. Annotations particularly relate to changes in orthographic and tone marking conventions over the years of collection and as compared to current practices
fields.label: provenance

fields.help: A language of the resource. Language is used for a language the resource is in (eg: English), as opposed to the language it describes (eg: Quechua).
fields.label: language

fields.help: URI to related resource(s).
fields.label: relation

datumFields.help: Use this field to establish your team's gramaticality/acceptablity judgements (*,#,? etc)
datumFields.label: judgement

datumFields.help: Use this as Line 1 in your examples for handouts (ie, either Orthography, or phonemic/phonetic representation)
datumFields.label: utterance

datumFields.help: This line is used to determine the morpheme segmentation to generate glosses, it also optionally can show up in your LaTeXed examples if you choose to show morpheme segmentation in addtion ot line 1, gloss and translation.
datumFields.label: morphemes

datumFields.help: This line appears in the gloss line of your LaTeXed examples, we reccomend Leipzig conventions (. for fusional morphemes, - for morpehem boundaries etc) The system uses this line to partially help you in glossing.
datumFields.label: gloss

datumFields.help: Use this as your primary translation. It does not need to be English, simply a language your team is comfortable with. If your consultant often gives you multiple languages for translation you can also add addtional translations in the customized fields. For example, your Quechua informants use Spanish for translations, then you can make all Translations in Spanish, and add an additional field for English if you want to generate a handout containing the datum.
datumFields.label: translation

datumFields.help: This field came from file import
datumFields.label: dateElicited

datumFields.help: This field came from file import
datumFields.label: notes

datumFields.help: This field came from file import
datumFields.label: checkedWithConsultant

datumFields.help: This field came from file import
datumFields.label: dialect

datumFields.help: Linguistic/social context when this can be said.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Linguistic/social context when this can be said, or when it is semantically/pragmatically felicitous etc.
datumFields.label: context

datumFields.help: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation).
datumFields.helpLinguists: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation). This can be in Wiki or LaTeX or plain text formatting
datumFields.label: documentation

datumFields.help: What was said/written using the alphabet/writing system of the language.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Orthographic transcription of the utterance; without morpheme breaks.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Many teams will only use the utterance line. However if your team needs to distinguish between utterance and orthography this is the unparsed word/sentence/dialog/paragraph/document in the language, in its native orthography. If there are more than one orthography an additional field can be added to the corpus. This is Line 0 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts (if you distinguish the orthography from the utterance line and you choose to display the orthography for your language consultants and/or native speaker linguists). Sample entry: amigas
datumFields.label: orthography

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes which match the spelling of the word (not necessarily the actual dictionary entry of the word) using a - between each eg: prefix-prefix-root-suffix-suffix-suffix.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A segmentation of the utterance into morphemes in their surface realizations.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Surface realizations of the morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Usually does not appear in your LaTeX examples unless you are working on morpho-phonology. Sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.label: allomorphs

datumFields.help: This is an optional field which can be used to help with search and data cleaning. eg: noun-thematicvowel-plural
datumFields.helpLinguists: A sequence of categories, one for each morpheme in the “morphemes” field.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: This optional field is used by the machine to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html
datumFields.label: syntacticCategory

datumFields.help: Related data in the database, or at any web url.
datumFields.label: relatedData

datumFields.help: Tags for categorizing your data.
datumFields.label: tags

datumFields.help: Tags about data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.helpLinguists: Tags specifically relevant to data validity, e.g., “NeedsToBeChecked”.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Any number of tags of data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.label: validationStatus

datumFields.help: The user who originally entered this.
datumFields.label: enteredByUser

datumFields.help: Users who modified this
datumFields.helpDevelopers: An array of users who modified this, this can optionally introduce a 'CheckedByUsername' into the datum's validation status if your team chooses.
datumFields.label: modifiedByUser

datumFields.help: This an optional field. If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.helpLinguists: A string-based representation of a syntax tree, i.e., a tree in bracket notation. We assume you will use the bracket notation conventions of The LaTeX tree-drawing package QTree, but you may use others if you wish.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: This optional field is used by the machine to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.label: syntacticTreeLatex

sessionFields.help: This describes the goals of the session.
sessionFields.label: goal

sessionFields.help: Example from DataOne: Format conventions: use uppercase ,Codes for missing values: unknown
sessionFields.label: consultants

sessionFields.help: You can use this field to be as precise as you would like about the dialect of this session.
sessionFields.label: dialect

sessionFields.help: This is the langauge (or language family) if you would like to use it.
sessionFields.label: language

sessionFields.help: This is the date in which the session took place.
sessionFields.label: dateElicited

sessionFields.help: Example from DataOne: Format conventions: use uppercase ,Codes for missing values: unknown
sessionFields.label: user

sessionFields.help: This is the date in which the session was entered.
sessionFields.label: dateSEntered

sessionFields.help: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants/publications/sources who were were the source/present for the data in this data session.
sessionFields.helpLinguists: A comma-separated list of sources (e.g., textual documents) for this entry.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants (usernames, or anonymous codes, or publication uri's) who were present for this elicitation session. This field also contains a (hidden) array of consultant/source masks if they are actual users of the system.
sessionFields.label: source

sessionFields.help: Social register of this example (friends, children speaking with children, formal, religious, ceremonial, etc.)
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is an optional field which indicates the social register of the example (friends, children speaking with children, formal, religious, ceremonial, etc.)
sessionFields.label: register

sessionFields.help: The GPS location of the elicitation session (if available)
sessionFields.label: location

sessionFields.help: A comma-separated list of the people who were present for this elicitation session, or of the authors/reviewers of the publication represented by this session.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is a comma separated field of all the people who were present for this elicitation session. This field also contains a (hidden) array of user masks with more details about the people present, if they are not anonymous or are actual users of the system.
sessionFields.label: participants

sessionFields.help: The date when the elicitation session data was entered into the computer.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: The date when the elicitation session data was actually entered in the computer (could be different from the dateElicited, especailly if you usually elicit data with an audio recorder and/or a note book).
sessionFields.label: DateSessionEntered

sessionFields.help: The optional device details of the equipment used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. e.g.: Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The optional device details of the equipment used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. e.g., Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: Your app can save optional anonymous device details of the equipment/software which used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. e.g.: Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.label: device

fields.mask:
Fieldwork in Batumi Georgia 2014

References/Tools:

 * Georgian transliterator (but just installing the keyboard seems to work well for typing in Georgian) http://ge.translit.cc/
 * Georgian romanization standards (including ipa) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Georgian
 * Georgian phrases with audio http://ggdavid.tripod.com/georgia/language/gphrases.htm
 * Georgian Phrases http://www.omniglot.com/language/phrases/georgian.php
 * Georgian Phrases http://mylanguages.org/georgian_phrases.php
 * Phrases and some discussion of pronunciation http://wikitravel.org/en/Georgian_phrasebook
 * http://www.inyourpocket.com/Georgia/Batumi
 * https://www.facebook.com/groups/Georgianwanderers/
 * http://omnestour.ge/travel-info/useful-georgian-phrases
 * Phrases with rather natural audio: http://ilanguages.org/georgian_phrases.php
 * Georgian news: http://www.reportiori.ge/?menuid=1&lang=1
 * Georgian OCR site (have to register but it works after that) http://www.targmne.com/OCR
 * Georgian Classifieds http://gancxadebebi.ge/
 * Georgian Alphabet Practice | Alphabet Training http://alphabettraining.com/mkhedruli-practice

fields.help: Entity/ies responsible for making contributions to the resource. A Contributor may be a person, an organization, or a service—any entity that has sufficient involvement in the creation or development of the resource to warrant explicit identification. A term from olac:role should be used to specify the role of the Contributor. Contributor is related to Creator since many of the terms in the role vocabulary (like author or photographer) name the role of the primary creator of a resource. The OLAC recommendation is that Contributor (with the appropriate role designation) be used in these cases, and that Creator be used only when there is not an appropriate term in the olac:role vocabulary for the role played by the entity that created the resource. A participating OLAC repository need not be concerned about the fact that other metadata services based on Dublin Core may prefer and even require the use of the Creator element. The OLAC-to-Simple-DC crosswalk built into the OLAC Aggregator automatically maps certain OLAC Contributor roles like author and photographer to the Creator element. See the discussion of Creator for more on its use. Follow the form in which the person's name would normally be listed in an alphabetical index in his or her own language or country of residence, e.g., “FamilyName, GivenName” for an English speaker. For examples see: http://www.language-archives.org/NOTE/usage.html

datumFields.help: Acceptablity judgement (*,#,?  mean this sentence is strange).
datumFields.helpLinguists: Grammaticality/acceptability judgement (*, #, ?, 1-3, etc.). Leave this field blank if this entry is grammatical/acceptable.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Grammaticality/acceptability judgement (*,#,?,1-3 etc). Leaving it blank usually means grammatical/acceptable, or your team can choose any symbol for this meaning.
datumFields.label: judgement

datumFields.help: What was said/written in an alphabet the team is comfortable using.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Transcription of the utterance, without morpheme breaks and probably orthographic.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Unparsed utterance in the language, in orthography or romanized or IPA transcription (what ever is commonly used for linguistic examples of this language.) Line 1 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts. Sample entry: amigas
datumFields.label: utterance

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes using a - between each eg: un-forget-able.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Morpheme-segmented utterance in the language, probably transcribed phonemically.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Can optionally appear below (or instead of) the first line in your LaTeXed examples. Sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.label: morphemes

datumFields.help: Translation for each prefix, root and suffix in the words.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A sequence of glosses (i.e., brief translations), one for each morpheme in the “morphemes” field.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Metalanguage glosses of each individual morpheme (above). Used by the system to help gloss, in combination with morphemes (above). It is Line 2 in your LaTeXed examples. We recommend Leipzig conventions (. for fusional morphemes, - for morpheme boundaries etc).  Sample entry: friend-fem-pl
datumFields.label: gloss

datumFields.help: Translation into English/Spanish/Russian, or simply a language the team is comfortable with. There may also be additional languages in the other fields.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A translation of the utterance in the language of analysis, i.e., the metalanguage.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: The team's primary translation. It might not be English, just a language the team is comfortable with (in which case you should change the lable to the language you are using). There may also be additional translations in the other fields.
datumFields.label: translation

datumFields.help: Linguistic/social context when this can be said.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Linguistic/social context when this can be said, or when it is semantically/pragmatically felicitous etc.
datumFields.label: context

datumFields.help: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation).
datumFields.helpLinguists: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation). This can be in Wiki or LaTeX or plain text formatting
datumFields.label: documentation

datumFields.help: What was said/written using the alphabet/writing system of the language.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Orthographic transcription of the utterance; without morpheme breaks.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Many teams will only use the utterance line. However if your team needs to distinguish between utterance and orthography this is the unparsed word/sentence/dialog/paragraph/document in the language, in its native orthography. If there are more than one orthography an additional field can be added to the corpus. This is Line 0 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts (if you distinguish the orthography from the utterance line and you choose to display the orthography for your language consultants and/or native speaker linguists). Sample entry: amigas
datumFields.label: orthography

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes which match the spelling of the word (not necessarily the actual dictionary entry of the word) using a - between each eg: prefix-prefix-root-suffix-suffix-suffix.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A segmentation of the utterance into morphemes in their surface realizations.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Surface realizations of the morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Usually does not appear in your LaTeX examples unless you are working on morpho-phonology. Sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.label: allomorphs

datumFields.help: This is an optional field which can be used to help with search and data cleaning. eg: noun-thematicvowel-plural
datumFields.helpLinguists: A sequence of categories, one for each morpheme in the “morphemes” field.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: This optional field is used by the machine to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html
datumFields.label: syntacticCategory

datumFields.help: Related data in the database, or at any web url.
datumFields.label: relatedData

datumFields.help: Tags for categorizing your data.
datumFields.label: tags

datumFields.help: Tags about data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.helpLinguists: Tags specifically relevant to data validity, e.g., “NeedsToBeChecked”.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Any number of tags of data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.label: validationStatus

datumFields.help: The user who originally entered this.
datumFields.label: enteredByUser

datumFields.help: Users who modified this
datumFields.helpDevelopers: An array of users who modified this, this can optionally introduce a 'CheckedByUsername' into the datum's validation status if your team chooses.
datumFields.label: modifiedByUser

datumFields.help: This an optional field. If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.helpLinguists: A string-based representation of a syntax tree, i.e., a tree in bracket notation. We assume you will use the bracket notation conventions of The LaTeX tree-drawing package QTree, but you may use others if you wish.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: This optional field is used by the machine to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). datumFields.helpDevelopers: Many teams will only use the utterance line. However if your team needs to distinguish between utterance and orthography this is the unparsed word/sentence/dialog/paragraph/document in the language, in its native orthography. If there are more than one orthography an additional field can be added to the corpus. This is Line 0 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts (if you distinguish the orthography from the utterance line and you choose to display the orthography for your language consultants and/or native speaker linguists). Sample entry: amigas
datumFields.label: orthography

datumFields.help: What was said/written in an alphabet the team is comfortable using.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Transcription of the utterance, without morpheme breaks and probably orthographic.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Unparsed utterance in the language, in orthography or romanized or IPA transcription (what ever is commonly used for linguistic examples of this language.) Line 1 in your LaTeXed examples for handouts. Sample entry: amigas
datumFields.label: utterance

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes using a - between each eg: un-forget-able.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Morpheme-segmented utterance in the language, probably transcribed phonemically.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Can optionally appear below (or instead of) the first line in your LaTeXed examples. Sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.label: morphemes

datumFields.help: Words divided into prefixes, root and suffixes which match the spelling of the word (not necessarily the actual dictionary entry of the word) using a - between each eg: prefix-prefix-root-suffix-suffix-suffix.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A segmentation of the utterance into morphemes in their surface realizations.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Surface realizations of the morpheme-segmented utterance in the language. Used by the system to help generate glosses (below). Usually does not appear in your LaTeX examples unless you are working on morpho-phonology. Sample entry: amig-a-s
datumFields.label: allomorphs

datumFields.help: Translation for each prefix, root and suffix in the words.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A sequence of glosses (i.e., brief translations), one for each morpheme in the “morphemes” field.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Metalanguage glosses of each individual morpheme (above). Used by the system to help gloss, in combination with morphemes (above). It is Line 2 in your LaTeXed examples. We recommend Leipzig conventions (. for fusional morphemes, - for morpheme boundaries etc).  Sample entry: friend-fem-pl
datumFields.label: gloss

datumFields.help: Translation into English, use по-русски for Russian version.
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Translation into English/Spanish/Russian, or simply a language the team is comfortable with. There may also be additional languages in the other fields.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A translation of the utterance in the language of analysis, i.e., the metalanguage.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: The team's primary translation. It might not be English, just a language the team is comfortable with (in which case you should change the lable to the language you are using). There may also be additional translations in the other fields.
datumFields.label: translation

datumFields.help: Translation into Russian
datumFields.helpNonLinguists: Translation into English/Spanish/Russian, or simply a language the team is comfortable with. There may also be additional languages in the other fields.
datumFields.helpLinguists: A translation of the utterance in the language of analysis, i.e., the metalanguage.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: The team's primary translation. It might not be English, just a language the team is comfortable with (in which case you should change the lable to the language you are using). There may also be additional translations in the other fields.
datumFields.label: russian

datumFields.help: Linguistic/social context when this can be said.
datumFields.helpLinguists: Linguistic/social context when this can be said, or when it is semantically/pragmatically felicitous etc.
datumFields.label: context

datumFields.help: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation).
datumFields.helpLinguists: Additional discussion of this example (for handouts or for documentation). This can be in Wiki or LaTeX or plain text formatting
datumFields.label: documentation

datumFields.help: This is an optional field which can be used to help with search and data cleaning. eg: noun-thematicvowel-plural
datumFields.helpLinguists: A sequence of categories, one for each morpheme in the “morphemes” field.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: This optional field is used by the machine to help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of syntactic category tagging you wish. It could be very theoretical like Distributed Morphology (Sample entry: √-GEN-NUM), or very a-theroretical like the Penn Tree Bank Tag Set. (Sample entry: NNS) http://www.ims.uni-stuttgart.de/projekte/CorpusWorkbench/CQP-HTMLDemo/PennTreebankTS.html
datumFields.label: syntacticCategory

datumFields.help: Related data in the database, or at any web url.
datumFields.label: relatedData

datumFields.help: Tags for categorizing your data.
datumFields.label: tags

datumFields.help: Tags about data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.helpLinguists: Tags specifically relevant to data validity, e.g., “NeedsToBeChecked”.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: Any number of tags of data validity. For example: ToBeCheckedBySeberina, CheckedByRicardo, Deleted etc...
datumFields.label: validationStatus

datumFields.help: The user who originally entered this.
datumFields.label: enteredByUser

datumFields.help: Users who modified this
datumFields.helpDevelopers: An array of users who modified this, this can optionally introduce a 'CheckedByUsername' into the datum's validation status if your team chooses.
datumFields.label: modifiedByUser

datumFields.help: This an optional field. If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.helpLinguists: A string-based representation of a syntax tree, i.e., a tree in bracket notation. We assume you will use the bracket notation conventions of The LaTeX tree-drawing package QTree, but you may use others if you wish.
datumFields.helpDevelopers: This optional field is used by the machine to make LaTeX trees and help with search and data cleaning, in combination with morphemes and gloss (above). If you want to use it, you can choose to use any sort of LaTeX Tree package (we use QTree by default) Sample entry: \Tree [.S NP VP ]
datumFields.label: syntacticTreeLatex

conversationFields.help: Use this field to keep track of who your speaker is. You can use names, initials, or whatever your consultants prefer.
conversationFields.helpLinguists: The speaker (or speakers) who produced or judged this utterance.
conversationFields.label: speakers

conversationFields.help: Use this field to indicate if this is a voice or gesture tier, or a tier for another modality.
conversationFields.label: modality

sessionFields.help: The goals of this text/transcript or elicitation session. Why did you get together today or why is this data being added to the database, was it the second day of field methods class, or you wanted to collect some stories from you grandmother, or was it to check on some data you found in the literature...
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The goal(s) that drove the elicitation session. For example, you may have wanted to collect stories or you may have had specific data questions relevant to a larger research question.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: The goals of the elicitation session. Why did you get together today, was it the second day of field methods class, or you wanted to collect some stories from you grandmother, or was it to check on some data you found in the literature...
sessionFields.label: goal

sessionFields.help: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants/publications/sources who were were the source/present for the data in this data session.
sessionFields.helpLinguists: A comma-separated list of sources (e.g., textual documents) for this entry.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is a comma seperated field of all the consultants (usernames, or anonymous codes, or publication uri's) who were present for this elicitation session. This field also contains a (hidden) array of consultant/source masks if they are actual users of the system.
sessionFields.label: source

sessionFields.help: Dialect of this example (city, village, region etc)
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The dialect represented by the data in this session.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This dialect may precise as the team chooses (province, region, city, village or any other measure of dialect)
sessionFields.label: dialect

sessionFields.help: Social register of this example (friends, children speaking with children, formal, religious, ceremonial, etc.)
sessionFields.helpLinguists: This is an optional field which indicates the social register of the example (friends, children speaking with children, formal, religious, ceremonial, etc.)
sessionFields.label: register

sessionFields.help: This is the langauge name (or language family), it is optionally tied to an Ethnologue language code (ISO 639-3).
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The language represented by the data in this session.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is the langauge (or language family), there is optional extra information fields if your team wants to tie it to an Ethnologe three letter language code (ISO 639-3).
sessionFields.label: language

sessionFields.help: The GPS location of the elicitation session (if available)
sessionFields.label: location

sessionFields.help: The date when the elicitation session took place, or when the data within it was spoken/published.
sessionFields.label: dateElicited

sessionFields.help: A comma-separated list of the people who were present for this elicitation session, or of the authors/reviewers of the publication represented by this session.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: This is a comma separated field of all the people who were present for this elicitation session. This field also contains a (hidden) array of user masks with more details about the people present, if they are not anonymous or are actual users of the system.
sessionFields.label: participants

sessionFields.help: The date when the elicitation session data was entered into the computer.
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: The date when the elicitation session data was actually entered in the computer (could be different from the dateElicited, especailly if you usually elicit data with an audio recorder and/or a note book).
sessionFields.label: dateSessionEntered

sessionFields.help: The optional device details of the equipment used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. e.g.: Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.helpLinguists: The optional device details of the equipment used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. e.g., Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.helpDevelopers: Your app can save optional anonymous device details of the equipment/software which used to record the elicitation session. This can be useful for measuring phonetic quality of the recording etc. e.g.: Nexus 7 Android 4.1
sessionFields.label: device

sessionFields.help: This is the username of who created this elicitation session. There are other fields contains an array of participants and source.
sessionFields.label: user

sessionFields.help: This field is deprecated, it was replaced by DateSessionEntered.
sessionFields.label: dateSEntered

speakerFields.help: A field to anonymously identify language speakers/participants.
speakerFields.helpLinguists: A field to anonymously identify language consultants/informants/experiment participants (by default it can be a timestamp, or a combination of experimenter initials, speaker/participant initials etc).
speakerFields.label: anonymousCode

speakerFields.help: The first name of the speaker/participant (optional, encrypted if speaker is anonymous)
speakerFields.helpLinguists: The first name of the speaker/participant (optional, should be encrypted if speaker should remain anonymous)
speakerFields.label: firstname

speakerFields.help: The last name of the speaker/participant (encrypted).
speakerFields.helpLinguists: The last name of the speaker/participant (optional, encrypted if speaker should remain anonymous).
speakerFields.label: lastname

speakerFields.help: Optional username of the speaker/participant, if the speaker/participant is registered in the system (encrypted).
speakerFields.label: username

speakerFields.help: Optional date of birth of the speaker/participant, if used by the experimental analysis (i.e., speaker/participants of 20 months performed differently from speaker/participants of 22 months).
speakerFields.label: dateOfBirth

speakerFields.help: Optional gender or biological sex of the speaker/participant, if used by the speaker/participants result reports or experimental analysis.
speakerFields.label: gender

speakerFields.help: This is the language name (or language family), it is optionally tied to an Ethnologue language code (ISO 639-3).
speakerFields.helpLinguists: This is the language (or language family), there are optional extra information fields if your team wants to tie it to an Ethnologue three letter language code (ISO 639-3).
speakerFields.label: languages

speakerFields.help: Confidentiality setting of this speaker. The default value is “anonymous”, which means that data can be associated to one speaker but the speaker cannot be identified. A value of “hidden” means data will be associated to the entire speaker population of the corpus. A value of “team” means that team members can see the consultant's identity but that viewers who are not team members can only see an anonymous user. A value of “public” means the speaker has signed a consent form and has asked that his/her data be associated to his/her user account or identity.
speakerFields.label: confidentiality

termsOfUse.humanReadable: Sample: The materials included in this corpus are available for research and educational use. If you want to use the materials for commercial purposes, please notify the curator(s) of the corpus (batumi-apps@googlegroups.com) prior to the use of the materials. Users of this corpus can copy and redistribute the materials included in this corpus, under the condition that the materials copied/redistributed are properly attributed.  Modification of the data in any copied/redistributed work is not allowed unless the data source is properly cited and the details of the modification is clearly mentioned in the work. Some of the items included in this corpus are subject to further access conditions specified by http://constcourt.ge
